| footnotes = }} '''Dennis Michael Miller''' (born November 3, 1953) is an American comedian, talk show host, political commentator, [[sports commentator]] and actor.
He was a cast member of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' from 1985 to 1991, and subsequently hosted a string of his own talk shows on [[HBO]], [[CNBC]], and in syndication. From 2007 to 2015, Miller hosted a daily, three-hour, self-titled talk radio program, nationally syndicated by [[Westwood One (current)|Westwood One]].<ref name=radioinsight/> He is known for his critical assessments of current events, laced with pop culture references and delivered in an idiosyncratic verbal style.
Miller is listed as 21st on [[Comedy Central]]'s 100 greatest stand up comedians of all time,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.listology.com/list/comedy-central-100-greatest-standups-all-time|title=Comedy Central 100 Greatest Standups of all Time|publisher=Listology.com|accessdate=21 September 2014}}</ref> and was ranked as the best host of SNL's ''[[Weekend Update]]'' by [[Vulture.com]].<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Vulture.com]]|date=May 17, 2014|title=A Complete Ranking of Saturday Night Live ‘Weekend Update’ Anchors|first=Dan|last=Reilly|url=http://www.vulture.com/2014/04/snl-weekend-update-anchors-ranking.html}}</ref>
==Early life== Miller was born in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, and grew up in the suburb of [[Castle Shannon, Pennsylvania|Castle Shannon]]. He is of [[Scottish people|Scottish]] descent.<ref name="washington">{{cite video|people=Miller, Dennis|title=Live from Washington, D.C. – They Shoot HBO Specials, Don't They?|medium=TV|publisher=[[HBO]]|date=1994-04-20}}</ref> Miller's parents separated and he was raised by his mother, Norma, a [[dietitian]] at a Baptist home.<ref>{{cite web|last=Myers|first=Chuck|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-63732934.html|title=1ST PERSON: Meet Dennis Miller|date=July 27, 2000|accessdate=2011-05-29}}</ref><ref name=Finder/> Miller is reticent to speak about his father, usually just saying he "moved on when I was very young."<ref name=Finder/> He is the oldest of Norma's five children, and in his early life often looked after the rest of his siblings.<ref name=Finder/>
===Primary school=== Miller attended [[Saint Anne School]], a Catholic elementary school.<ref name=Wood/> Miller's personality during this period was not one of an innate performer but of a shy kid.<ref name=Finder>{{cite news|title=Dennis Miller: Monday Night Live|date=July 30, 2000|author=Chuck Finder|url=http://old.post-gazette.com/sports_headlines/20000730miller4.asp}}</ref> Miller's childhood pastimes included playing street football, backyard baseball, playing basketball at St. Anne's and watching lots of television.<ref name=Finder/> At St. Anne's Miller served as manager for the Catholic Youth Organization basketball team for boys 15 to 16 years-old.<ref name=Finder/> Miller's first inspiration to pursue a comedy career came as a child when he was taken to see comedian [[Kelly Monteith]] at a Pittsburgh club. After the show Monteith was kind enough to answer the young Miller's questions about being a comedian, leaving him thinking "Man, I'm going to work hard at this; ...seems like fun."<ref name=Roe>{{cite news|title=Hey, Cha Cha – Dennis Miller brings his snarky shtick to Austin|author=Dale Roe|work=American-Statesman|url=http://www.mystatesman.com/lifestyles/hey-cha-cha-dennis-miller-brings-his-snarky-shtick-austin/9Wgthda6QHqbO7KqMJWtGL/}}</ref>
===High school=== Miller went on to [[Keystone Oaks High School]].<ref name=Wood>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/weekend/people/people-wood020202.shtml|title=People: Peter Wood on Dennis Miller on NRO Weekend|work=National Review|accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> His two earliest childhood comedy heroes were [[Jonathan Winters]] and [[Tim Conway]].<ref>{{cite interview|last= Miller|first=Dennis|interviewer=Dennis Miller|title=The Dennis Miller Show|last2=Conway|first2=Tim|url=http://www.dennismillerradio.com/blog?action=blogArchive&blogTag=Tim%20Conway|date=2013-11-01}}</ref> By high school he had already developed a reputation for humor.<ref name=Finder/> Miller and his brother Rich had an open invitation to the home of his best friend Ted Wasik. The Wasik parents, Pauline and Ted "Herc" Wasik, Sr., treated Miller as one of their own. Pauline later recalled that Miller would often stage his comedy during a meal, which irritated her husband because the laughter distracted the rest of the children from eating.<ref name=Finder/> At Keystone Oaks, Miller was a member of the Physical Fitness Club, and in his senior year he worked on the Keynote newspaper and served on student council (he lost his bid for senior-class president to Richard Yount).<ref name=Finder/> During his senior year, he also served as co-master of ceremonies for the Keystone Oaks May Pageant, themed "Once Upon A Rumble Seat."<ref name=Finder/> Despite Miller's reputation for humor, his actual personality at this time was one that was reserved, lacking self-confidence, and hidden under a layer of comedy.<ref name=Finder/> He graduated from high school in 1971 with the intent of studying to become a sports writer.<ref name=Wood/><ref name=Finder/>
===University=== At [[Point Park University]] Miller became a member of [[Sigma Tau Gamma]] fraternity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baylorsigtau.com/page.php?page_id=4056 |title=Welcome to Sigma Tau Gamma, Gamma Omega Chapter |publisher=Baylorsigtau.com|accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> Miller likened his social status at this period as being lower than [[Curtis Armstrong|Booger]] of ''[[Revenge of the Nerds]]''.<ref>{{cite book|title=I Rant, Therefore I Am|author=Dennis Miller|publisher=Doubleday|date=2000|page=126}}</ref>
Inspired by the film ''[[All the President's Men (film)|All the President's Men]]'', Miller majored in journalism. In the fall of his senior year at the university, Miller began writing for the South Hills Record, mixing humor into his sports reporting. When the paper changed its payment structure to pay around an eighth of a penny per column inch, Miller quit.<ref name=Finder/> Miller graduated from Point Park in 1976 with a degree in journalism.<ref name="TVG bio">{{cite web|title=Dennis Miller Biography|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/dennis-miller/bio/147096|work=TV Guide|accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Finder/> Miller would later reflect on why he did not continue to pursue journalism, saying "I'm just not that interested in other people's business and that's a tragic flaw in a journalist."<ref name=Tulsa/>
===Career search=== After college, Miller was unable to find work in journalism. Instead, he moved through several occupations, including a clerk at Giant Eagle deli, a janitor, a delivery man for a florist, and an ice cream scooper at the Village Dairy.<ref name=Finder/> Reflecting on his pre-comedy job history in a later discussion with [[Tom Snyder]], Miller recalled leaving college and attending a real estate seminar at a "bad hotel," which consisted of a five-hour lecture without bathroom breaks. Near the end of the lecture, he was told that he would only be paid by commission, which made Miller say "I'm in Hell, I don't even know what I am going to do for a living here. I'm a nut case." Miller then worked as a delivery man for what he describes as "an all-gay florist." Leaving that job, he worked as an ice cream scooper. Miller recalled that he was twenty-one—five years out of high school and wearing a paper hat while working alongside teens excited about getting their driver's licenses. A spur to quit the ice cream scooping job was when the prettiest girl he had attended high school with came in and he was the one who had to take her order, which filled him with embarrassment.<ref name=Tom>{{cite video|title=1995-Dennis Miller|publisher=The Late Late Show with Tom Snyder|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uWAyOAz2xkU|date=July 28, 1995}}</ref> Miller later stated that at the time he feared that if he stayed in such jobs, his life would become a [[Franz Kafka]] novella, and it stiffened his resolve to start pursuing a comedy career.<ref name=Joke/>
Leaving the ice cream parlor, Miller joined the staff at Point Park's Recreation Room, where he was in charge of the bowling alley, video games, and running the air-hockey league.<ref name=Finder/> Air-hockey regulars nicknamed him "Clarence" after NHL Commissioner [[Clarence Campbell,]] or called him "Commish." When Miller's brother Jimmy was around, they referred to him as "Commush".<ref name=Finder/> A patron from that time recalled that Miller sat on pool tables telling jokes and honing his comedy to those in the rec room, which was the only place the commuters gathered. Miller and the other patrons closely followed the NFL at the time as it was the "[[Pittsburgh Steelers#The Chuck Noll era|era of the Super Steelers]]".<ref name=Finder/>
===Beginning stand-up=== In 1979 after seeing a [[Robin Williams]] comedy special on HBO, Miller decided that he had to pursue his dream of being a stand-up comedian.<ref name=Finder/>
In Pittsburgh Miller began pursuing a comedy career by performing at open-mic nights. He backed out of his first two attempts to perform at an open mic due to stage fright and anger with himself over the question of whether the drive to perform was a need for approval from others.<ref name=Duncan>{{cite news|work=Los Angeles Times|date=June 11, 1989|author=Duncan Strauss|title=He's Brainy, Funny--and Frightened?|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-11/entertainment/ca-3378_1_stand-up-fresh-air-real-life}}</ref> When he finally made his début at the Oak's Lounge on Sleepy Hollow Road in Castle Shannon, most of Miller's family was in the audience to cheer him on.<ref name=Julina>{{cite news|title=Comic Killing' Em With Gags|author=Mike Julina|date=February 23, 1980|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|page=12|url= https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/88936157/}}</ref>
In a later interview, Miller spoke of the stage presence he developed for his stand-up act to address his fears. (He emphasized that the comedy business will always be frightening as any error could spiral into the end of a career.) To compensate for his early fears, Miller said, "I got up there and acted like the guy I always wanted to be to get through it. ...It's a part of me, but it's not the real me." He would keep his hands in his pockets to appear unfazed, or adjust his cuffs during an audience laugh to give the appearance of indifference to approval. Miller pointed out that part of his act is to show a "hipper-than-thou" persona, but then purposely undermine it at regular intervals for comedic effect.<ref name=Duncan/>
He began appearing onstage at the Oak's Lounge in Castle Shannon while working at the Giant Eagle deli in [[Kennedy Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Kennedy]].<ref name=Finder/> Miller lived without a car and without much money in the [[Oakland (Pittsburgh)|Oakland neighborhood of Pittsburgh,]] hitching rides or taking buses.<ref name=Finder/> He continued to do stand-ups in Oakland and at places like Brandy's in the Strip District and the Portfolio on Craig Street, eventually saving up $1,000 which he used to try to fast-track his comedy career by moving to New York City.<ref name=Finder/><ref name=Julina/> Arriving there, Miller had to bribe a landlord $200 to give him a room, then had to pay the security deposit of $250 and the first month's rent of $250, resulting in his having spent $700 of his $1,000 savings the first day for a sparse, bunker-like room.<ref name=Julina/>
While in New York he submitted a joke for a ''Playboy'' magazine contest for humor writing that was judged by an all-star panel including [[Rodney Dangerfield]], [[Bill Cosby]], [[David Brenner]], [[Martin Mull]], [[Art Buchwald]], and [[Buck Henry]].<ref name=Julina/> Of around 15,000 entries, Miller tied for second and his joke and picture appeared in the June 1979 issue of the magazine.<ref name=Duncan/><ref name=Julina/> Miller won $500 as a runner-up in ''Playboy''{{'}}s first annual humor competition with the following joke: {{quote|The only difference between group sex and group therapy is that in group therapy you hear about everyone's problems, and in group sex you see them.|Dennis Miller|''Playboy'', June 1979<ref>{{cite news|date=June 1979|title=Funny Money|magazine=Playboy|volume=26|number=6|issn=0032-1478}}</ref>}}
For the first year and a half of his comedy career, Miller had heavily relied on props during his act, but he felt this limited him and switched to using purely language.<ref name=Duncan/>
Miller gained more exposure when he tried out for the New York Laff-Off Contest. The contest had 40 slots but 32 of them had already been filled by the top regulars who appeared at the three comedy venues sponsoring the competition. 350 people tried out for the remaining eight slots, some of whom had appeared on [[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]], [[The Merv Griffin Show]], or [[The Mike Douglas Show]]. Many of the comedians Miller was up against had hours of crafted material, while he had fine-tuned around ten minutes. To his surprise and delight, Miller earned one of the remaining slots. For the competition itself he appeared at the Improv and received a standing ovation, moving him onto the finals. While he did not win the Laff-Off, he was seen by dozens of talent agents, resulting in bookings at colleges and other clubs.<ref name=Julina/>
While he was working in New York City, ''[[Hustler Magazine]]'' listed Miller in a piece called "The 10 Funniest People in America You'll Never See on TV."<ref name=Julina/>
While in New York City, Miller supported himself by working rather mundane jobs during the day, such as bartender and payroll clerk, and by night made the rounds of New York clubs The Comic Strip, The Improvisation, and Catch a Rising Star.<ref name=Julina/> After about a year, unable to make a go of it, he returned to Pittsburgh.<ref name=Finder/><ref name=Duncan/>
==Television career== Having honed his stand-up comedy act, Miller was able to transition to television, increasing his audience base.
===KDKA-TV=== Having gone through the comedy-club circuit, Miller returned to do his sight-gag routine back in Pittsburgh at Brandy's in August 1980. It was there that local television station [[KDKA-TV]] was shooting a piece for its ''Evening Magazine'' and offered him a job at the station. By the end of 1980 Miller acted as a warm-up in the afternoons for KDKA's ''Pittsburgh 2Day''. He then began starring in humorous segments for the syndicated ''[[Evening Magazine]]''. By 1983 he had become the host of ''Punchline,'' a Saturday-morning [[newsmagazine]] aimed at teenagers. In one episode he interviewed fellow comedian [[Pat Paulsen]]. Miller later reflected on this time, saying that "you have to start somewhere", and that he was "just pleased to be in front of a camera."<ref name=Finder/><ref>{{cite web|author=The Comedy Zone Humor Network |url=http://www.comedy-zone.net/standup/comedian/m/miller-dennis.htm |title=Dennis Miller : Comedian Profile |publisher=Comedy-zone.net |accessdate=2010-10-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612030529/http://comedy-zone.net/standup/comedian/m/miller-dennis.htm |archivedate=June 12, 2010 }}</ref>
During this time Miller also performed stand-up in New York City comedy clubs such as [[Catch a Rising Star (comedy clubs)|Catch A Rising Star]] and The Comic Strip. While in New York, Miller saw a show by [[Richard Belzer]] and noted how he barked at the crowd rather than embraced it, was cutting rather than cute. Miller adopted this comedic philosophy.<ref name=Finder/>
During performances at comedy clubs in Pittsburgh, Miller befriended [[Jay Leno]] and [[Jerry Seinfeld]]. In 1984 Leno found Miller an apartment in Los Angeles and he and Seinfeld arranged a début for Miller at [[The Improv]].<ref name=Finder/><ref name=Joke/> Miller resigned from KDKA and moved to Los Angeles to try to further his comedy career.
Miller's brothers Rich and Jimmy joined him in Los Angeles, taking up varied jobs around The Improv such as booking shows, acting as bouncer, and selling tickets. Jimmy would go on to become a power talent agent with Gold Miller, and Rich would run RCM Entertainment, booking comedians across the country.<ref name=Finder/>
In Los Angeles, Leno was a big influence on Miller as he was to many upcoming comedians in the area at the time. Young comedians would gather at Leno's home late at night and he would offer critiques with humorous, biting wit. Leno would also tape television appearances of his group and show them during such sessions while offering more humorous critiques. Miller would later fondly recall the time, saying it was like "sitting at his knee, querying [[Yoda]]".<ref name=Finder/>
Miller appeared on ''[[Star Search]]'', where he lost out to fellow comedian [[Sinbad (comedian)|Sinbad]] after the two tied with judges' scores, but Sinbad won with a higher studio-audience approval rating. Miller made his first appearance on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' on June 24, 1985 (other guests that night were [[Phil Collins]] and [[María Conchita Alonso]]).<ref name=Joke/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=epguides.com|url=http://epguides.com/LateNightwithDavidLetterman/|title=Late Night with David Letterman (a Guest Stars & Air Dates Guide)}}</ref>
===''Saturday Night Live''=== Miller's big break came in 1985 when he was discovered by [[Lorne Michaels]] at [[The Comedy Store]]. Michaels had him come in for an audition. Miller did an audition in L.A. for SNL and that went well enough for him to be brought to New York for a second audition in a room in Times Square. About 70 people watched this second audition—this was most of the show's staff along with Lorne Michaels, Paul Simon, and Dan Aykroyd. Miller walked into a well-lit room and was told "Go ahead, you have eight minutes, Dennis."<ref name=Roe/> After the New York audition he went to dinner with Michaels and Jack Nicholson. Miller felt that this was just another aspect of his audition, to see if he could handle himself around famous people, so he "just sat there quietly".<ref name=Roe/>
Miller later recalled the conclusion of the meeting with Michaels: "He looked at me and goes, 'Would you like to do my newscast?'. And I said, 'Yeah, I would', and he said, 'Well, I'll see you tomorrow'. And then I walked out. And I remember thinking, 'My life has just changed'."<ref name=Joke/> Miller had landed a spot on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', where he succeeded [[Christopher Guest]] as the ''[[Weekend Update]]'' anchor. The spot was supposed to go to comic [[Jon Lovitz]], but Lovitz was scheduled for other parts on the show and needed the ''Update'' segment to do costume changes, so Miller was drafted to read the news.<ref name="penn">{{cite episode|title=Penn Jillette Radio Show. Special Guest: Dennis Miller |url=https://archive.org/download/Penn_Radio_archive/The.Penn.Jillette.Radio.Show.2006.09.22.mp3| series=[[Penn Radio]] |airdate=2006-09-22}}</ref> Miller had not been particularly political in his comedy before SNL but found that it came easy—he could open a newspaper and find a few headlines to build a new act around.<ref name=split>{{cite web|title= Saturday Night's Children: Dennis Miller (1985-1991)|author=Megh Wright|date=January 24, 2012|work=Splitsider|url=http://splitsider.com/2012/01/saturday-nights-children-dennis-miller-1985-1991/}}</ref> He decided to make his stage persona a bit cynical, as he felt that people who had tried to do the ''Weekend Update'' segment as nice guys did not last very long in the role.<ref name=Adams>{{cite news|title=Sardonic Dennis Miller employs verbal humor to comment on society|date=July 28, 1991|author=Eric Adams|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1991-07-28/features/1991209154_1_dennis-miller-miller-show-howie|work=The Baltimore Sun}}</ref>
Miller began his fictional news reports with "Good evening, and what can I tell you?" and closed with "Guess what, folks? That's the news, and I am outta here!". Fans of ''SNL'' became accustomed to his snarky delivery, high-pitched giggle, and frequently primped hair—idiosyncrasies that would be spoofed by [[Dana Carvey]], [[Tom Hanks]], and [[Jimmy Fallon]], all of whom have impersonated Miller on the show. When Miller left ''SNL'' in 1991, the anchor's chair was turned over to [[Kevin Nealon]].
In 1988, Miller released a stand-up comedy CD, ''The Off-White Album'', derived from an [[HBO]] special titled ''Mr. Miller Goes to Washington'',<ref>{{IMDb title|0249466|Mr. Miller Goes to Washington Starring Dennis Miller (1988) }}</ref> which drew heavily from the [[Observational comedy|observational]] and [[metaphor]]-driven style he was known for on ''Saturday Night Live'', and showed glimpses of the political humor that would influence his later work. A well-received HBO special, ''Dennis Miller: Black and White'',<ref>{{IMDb title|0317340|Dennis Miller: Black and White, (1990)}}</ref> aired shortly after the release of the CD.
Although Miller spent much of his time on ''SNL'' behind the ''Weekend Update'' desk, he was included in some sketches and did a few recurring characters and celebrity impersonations.<ref name="snl archives">[http://snl.jt.org/cast.php?i=DeMi Dennis Miller], SNL Archives</ref>
====Recurring characters==== * Koko, one of the pixies in the recurring sketch "Miss Connie's Fable Nook" * Steve, one of The Stand-Ups (others include [[Jon Lovitz]] as Bob, [[Damon Wayans]] as Keith, and [[Tom Hanks]] as Paul)
====Celebrity impersonations==== * [[Gary Hart]] * [[George Harrison]] * [[Nathaniel Crosby]]
===''The Dennis Miller Show''=== In 1992, after leaving SNL, Miller hosted an eponymous late-night talk show in [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] that lasted seven months.
====Late-night landscape==== ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'' was launched in 1989, and after Tribune Entertainment saw how that show brought in new and younger viewers to late night, they wanted to make their own show in an attempt to match its success.<ref name=Phil>{{cite news|title=Talk With A 'tude|date=January 20, 1992|author=Phil Rosenthal|work=Los Angeles Daily News|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-01-20/lifestyle/9201181129_1_dennis-miller-miller-show-miller-brings}}</ref> In 1990 Tribune Entertainment pursued [[Garry Shandling]] to create a syndicated late-night talk show, reaching out to him through the talent agency that represented him [[Brillstein Entertainment Partners|Brillstein-Grey Entertainment]]. When Shandling turned down the offer, Brillsten-Grey recommended Miller, who was another of their clients.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shandling finds the grass still greener on his side of the talk-show fence|date=June 1, 1993|author=David Zurawik|work=Baltimore Sun|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-06-01/features/1993152130_1_garry-shandling-larry-sanders-show-talk-show}}</ref><ref name=Phil/> The drive for Tribune to come out with a new show increased when in May 1991 Johnny Carson announced he would be retiring. As it became apparent that Jay Leno would take Carson's place and as the time slot was at that point only contested by ''The Arsenio Hall Show'', Tribune felt that if Leno could not hold onto Carson's fans they might migrate to a newer show.<ref name=Carman>{{cite news|title=Weeknight update: Dennis Miller debuts|date=January 20, 1992|author=John Carman|work=The Baltimore Sun|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1992-01-20/features/1992020185_1_dennis-miller-arsenio-hall-miller-show}}</ref> Miller was approached with an offer where Tribune Entertainment would distribute the show and Miller would co-produce the show with Brillstein-Grey Company.<ref name=Allan>{{cite news|date=January 19, 1992|author=Allan Johnson|work=Chicago Tribune|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-01-19/entertainment/9201060005_1_dennis-miller-show-weekend-update-studio-audience|title=Dennis Thinks It's Miller Time on Talk Show Circuit}}</ref> Miller and the others involved felt even more secure in their position when Leno was picked to replace Carson over David Letterman, who it was thought would renew his contract with NBC till at least 1993. It was believed that fans of Letterman would naturally be interested in Miller's show and prefer that over Leno's in that time slot.<ref name=Phil/>
====Leaving SNL==== Miller decided he was going to leave SNL after the 1990-91 season despite being happy with his role on the show and despite loving writing political gags for it, because he had turned 38 and his 18-month-old son Holden had made him want to strive for things to "make the boy proud."<ref name=Allan/><ref name=Adams/> He told an interviewer, "I had a great gig and this came up. It seemed like an opportunity that doesn't present itself too frequently in your life, so I opted to take it. ...I wanted to see what other talents I had, so I decided this was the shot."<ref name=Adams/> Miller thought that his outspokenness behind the SNL desk on political topics and even on jokes not working out made the transition to talk show host a good idea. He also felt that the SNL studio audience never fully accepted him in skits as other characters, making him question his acting ability.<ref name=Allan/>
After it was announced that Miller would be starting his own show, he was a guest on ''The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson'', who offered him some advice while reflecting on his own 30-year career from which he was retiring in May 1992. He told Miller to compete only with himself, not to focus on the competition. Miller appreciated the advice, noting that "there's no class for this" and that he would have to learn on the job in front of an audience.<ref name=Allan/> In preparation, Miller sharpened his interviewing skills by practicing on the show's stage hands. He felt that the secret to interviewing well was listening to the guest rather than trying to set up jokes while the guest is talking.<ref name=Allan/>
As the date for the show's opening approached, Miller told an interviewer that he was both thrilled and "scared shitless" by the opportunity. He hoped to eventually be able to relax enough to be entirely himself. He saw Johnny Carson's approach as the standard but hoped not to be too influenced by anyone.<ref name=Adams/> Between SNL and his new show, Miller did stand-up dates with [[Howie Mandel]] and then with [[Steven Wright]].<ref name=Adams/>
====The show's early days==== In support of the show's premiere, Tribune made use of extensive advertising in trade publications and on-air promotions and also did a billboard promotion on Sunset Boulevard.<ref name=Hastings/>
On January 20, 1992, following his departure from ''Saturday Night Live'', Miller launched the late-night TV talk show, ''The Dennis Miller Show'', syndicated by [[Tribune Entertainment]]. ''The Dennis Miller Show'' continued in the tradition of "[[Alternative culture|alternative]]" talk shows, starting with the ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' show, which debuted on [[NBC]] in 1982. [[Nick Bakay]] was the announcer, and [[Andy Summers]], formerly of the band [[The Police]], led the house band.
Guests included [[Mountain (band)|Mountain]] (with [[Leslie West]] and [[Corky Laing]]), [[Toad the Wet Sprocket]] (who made their national television debut on the show), [[Henry Rollins]] (who appeared repeatedly to chat with Miller and perform [[spoken word]]), [[Primus (band)|Primus]] (who while performing "[[Tommy the Cat]]", had to deal with a member of the audience who jumped onstage—whom Miller playfully tried to "tackle"), [[King's X]] (who performed two songs, "[[Black Flag (song)|Black Flag]]" and "[[It's Love]]" to empty seats in the studio due to the [[1992 Los Angeles riots]]), and comedian [[Bill Hicks]].
The show remained faithful to the classic talk-show format with a desk and three or four guests a night, while Miller carried forward the spirit of his SNL ''Weekend Update'' with a newscast segment that aired on Fridays.<ref name=Adams/><ref name=Allan/>
The show's staff boasted a mix of past and future performers, writers, and producers of note including [[Mark Brazill]] (''[[That '70s Show]]''), Eddie Feldmann, [[David Kohan]] and [[Max Mutchnick]] (creators of ''[[Will & Grace]]''), [[Norm Macdonald]], [[Bob Odenkirk]] (''[[Mr. Show]]''), [[John Riggi]], [[Kevin Rooney]], [[Herb Sargent]] (''[[Saturday Night Live]]''), [[Drake Sather]], and [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]] (''[[Second City TV]]'').
Miller thought there would be room for his show as its main competitors for the time slot would be ''The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'' and ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'' and he felt they all attracted different audiences.<ref name=Allan/> At the time [[Arsenio Hall]] was not worried about Jay Leno's hold on late night, but told the Los Angeles Times, "Dennis Miller is the only one who scares me, because I have tremendous respect for him and think he's one of the brightest comics on the scene."<ref name=Phil/><ref>{{cite news|title=The Arsenio Way : No Carson Copycat, Hall Woofs Up His Audience By Making His Own Rules|date=January 5, 1992|author=Dabuek Cerone|work=Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-01-05/news/tv-2136_1_arsenio-hall}}</ref>
The show opened to mixed reviews, with some being "blisteringly negative", but Tribune remained optimistic, saying that a 2 rating nationally would be acceptable due to the late hour of the show and pointed out that in some places Miller was doing better than Hall.<ref>{{cite news|title=Reporter's Notebook|author=Bill Carter|date=February 4, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/04/arts/reporter-s-notebook-rather-pulls-cbs-news-back-to-the-assassination.html|work=New York Times}}</ref> As the show progressed, national ratings were still behind Hall (whose show was also syndicated). In the first five weeks of Miller's show, the national A.C. Nielsen Co. rating was 1.8 (around 1.6 million homes) to Hall's 3.4 over the same time-period.<ref name=Cerone/> Media watchers noted that, in contrast, Hall's 1989 debut had numbers between 3 and 3.5 and that the industry standard for long-term survival at the time was a minimum of 2.<ref name=Cerone/> In order to address this shortfall and in anticipation of Carson leaving and his audience being up for grabs, Tribune began making changes.<ref name=Cerone/> In February 1992, Andy Summers announced that since helping to launch the show and writing its theme music, he should move on to focus instead on his solo career.<ref>{{cite news|title=Television|date=February 19, 1992|work=Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-02-19/entertainment/ca-2164_1_dennis-miller-show}}</ref> Summers had developed a different musical vision for the show than the traditional rock 'n' roll that Tribune wanted. He was replaced by David Goldblatt, who had been [[Diana Ross]]'s musical director for her 1989 world tour.<ref name=Cerone>{{cite news|title='Miller' Doing What It Can So It Won't Be Outta There|date=March 11, 1992|author=Daniel Cerone|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-11/entertainment/ca-3405_1_talk-show}}</ref> By March 1992 Tribune Entertainment decided it wanted more of the show's focus to be on Miller and his comedy and less on the guests, as testing had shown the audience tuned in for Miller's opening monologue but often tuned away when he was talking to guests.<ref name=Cerone/> To facilitate this change, Ken Ehrlich was moved to being a musical consultant and replaced in his co-executive-producer duties by Laurence Ferber, who had been able to restructure ''[[The Joan Rivers Show]]'' to increase ratings by bringing it more in line with her personality.<ref>{{cite news|title=Television|date=March 6, 1992|author=Aleene MacMinn|work=The Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-06/entertainment/ca-3266_1_dennis-miller-show}}</ref><ref name=DMN>{{cite news|title=Follow Miller's Clued-in Show? You're With The 'Coolest of Cool'|date=May 5, 1992|work=Dallas Morning News|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-05-05/lifestyle/9205030601_1_dennis-miller-miller-show-ann-reinking}}</ref><ref name=Cerone/> It was at this time that Dave Thomas was brought in as a writer to "open up the comedy", with the hope he could develop bits for Miller where he would interact more with the crowd.<ref name=Cerone/> Tribune remained optimistic that the numbers could rise and pointed out that the show had strong demographics, skewing heavily towards young men—a target audience for many advertisers. Media watchers noted that Tribune had lowered its ad prices since failing to live up to its original ratings estimates.<ref name=Cerone/> Tribune insisted that "We don't think of our shows in terms of some kind of death period," and pointed out that it took two years for ''The Joan Rivers Show'', then in its fourth year, to get off the ground.<ref name=Cerone/>
===="The Booking Wars"==== To differentiate himself from Arsenio, Miller wanted to have a mix of Hollywood celebrities, authors, and political figures on the show, early on having guests like [[Larry Miller (comedian)|Larry Miller]], [[Sally Kirkland]], [[Clive Barker]], [[Michael Kinsley]], [[Tom Hanks]], [[Christian Slater]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Al Gore]], and [[Benjamin Netanyahu]].<ref name=Phil/>
A few weeks in, the show began encountering problems booking guests, with some media outlets such as the Dallas Morning News wondering if it was Miller's interview style, where "Miller messes around with them as best he can, looking for openings to throw a jab or two or 10."<ref name=DMN/> In response Miller said he did not want to always be "a faceless, selfless conduit of information", he did not want to be another [[Larry King]] saying one or two words between guests' speeches. Nor did he want to be like Arsenio Hall, who was seen as fawning over guests on his show. Miller felt he was attracting an audience that wanted a "different, funky vibe".<ref name=DMN/><ref name=Phil/><ref>{{cite news|title=Tv Looks To Night Owls in Hopes of Golden Eggs|date=August 12, 1991|author=Jonathan Storm|work=Orlando Sentinel|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1991-08-12/lifestyle/9108100487_1_arsenio-ron-reagan-show-miller-show}}</ref>
Some controversy occurred around an episode involving guest performance artist [[Karen Finley]]. In her piece, she characterized abortion as pouring Drano into a woman's vagina and said she wanted to "feminize the planet to overthrow this male control of our lives." Afterwards, Miller interviewed her and defended her right of expression. Tribune later pulled the episode from its scheduled July 14 air-time, then cut out her segment and aired the rest on July 17. Finley accused the show of censoring her. She told a reporter "I think Dennis Miller is just as bad as [[Jesse Helms]]. What's the difference?". Tribune said that they had taken this action not for political reasons but "the inappropriateness of including the segment in a music, comedy and light-entertainment program".<ref>{{cite news|date=July 16, 1992|work=Los Angeles Times|author=Daniel Cerone|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-07-16/local/me-3724_1_performance-artist|title=Performance Artist Charges Censorship}}</ref>
The main reason the show had problems booking guests was that [[Helen Kushnick]], executive producer for ''The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'', let it be known that anyone appearing on a competing talk show would never be invited on Leno's program.<ref name=Finder/><ref name=Pierce>{{cite news|title=Late-Night Talk-Show Battle has gotten a lot Tighter|author=Scott D. Pierce|date=May 5, 1995|work=Deseret News|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/419295/LATE-NIGHT-TALK-SHOW-BATTLE-HAS-GOTTEN-A-LOT-TIGHTER.html?pg=all}}</ref> As accusations of unethical booking pressures were made first by Hall and then by Miller, the media began to describe the situation as "The Booking Wars."<ref name=Hastings/><ref name=Harris>{{cite news|title=Jay Leno's late-night war|author=Mark Harris|date=August 14, 1992|work=Entertainment Weekly|url=http://ew.com/article/1992/08/14/jay-lenos-late-night-war/2/}}</ref>
Miller, realizing upfront that his show would have trouble competing with more established late-night talk shows, told his show's talent booker not to attempt to compete for famous guests. Instead he wanted to go after "fringe players" and, invoking [[Gertrude Stein]] he said he wanted to set a mood of "an eclectic sense of [[Salon (gathering)|salon]]."<ref name=Campus>{{cite video|title=When Jay Leno Pissed Off Dennis Miller|work=CampusInsiders|date=October 15, 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4wQgZ4JjUdY}}</ref> He later recalled that even this approach did not prevent problems with Leno's show. After Miller's talent booker had booked the aborigine drum band [[Yothu Yindi]], whom Miller described as "It's like five guys in thongs with small logs beating big logs".<ref name=Campus/> To Miller's astonishment, Yothu Yindi cancelled their appearance because they were worried that if they appeared on his show they would be banned from the ''Tonight Show''. Miller called Leno and complained loudly and with expletives, so they "butted heads for a while".<ref name=Campus/> Miller and Leno would not talk to each other for several years afterwards.<ref name=Pierce/> While Yothu Yindi did wind up appearing on the show, [[P. J. O'Rourke]], who after a six-month negotiation was set to appear on the show, cancelled and appeared with Leno. Miller openly denounced O'Rourke on his show.<ref name=Boreske>{{cite news|title=Dennis Miller's Talk Show Dies|author=Pat H. Broeske|date=July 31, 1992|work=Entertainment Weekly|url=http://ew.com/article/1992/07/31/dennis-millers-talk-show-dies/}}</ref> He even pleaded for guests on air, giving the show's office number.<ref name=Boreske/> Rather than just rely on the talent agent, Miller began calling people personally to invite them to be guests on his show.<ref name=Hastings/>
====Cancellation & after-effects==== On July 17, 1992, Tribune Entertainment announced it was cancelling Miller's show due to poor ratings. Donald Hacker, its president and chief executive officer, said "After a tremendous effort on the parts of all parties involved, we've made a business decision not to proceed." The last show would be July 24, 1992.<ref>{{cite news|title=Comedian Is Outta Here - Miller's Show Canceled|date=July 18, 1992|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-07-18/news/9207180853_1_tribune-entertainment-comedian-chicago-tribune}}</ref> Tribune issued an odd, single-spaced, five-page press release that praised the show, its ratings, its guests, and its segments (no mention was made of profits).<ref>{{cite news|title=Front and Center|date=July 19, 1992|author=Kathy O'Malley|work=Chicago Tribune|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-07-19/features/9203050129_1_illinois-rich-daley-bill-clinton}}</ref> Tribune also took out a two-page ad spread in the Hollywood Reporter, which thanked Miller and the guests of his show.<ref name=Hastings>{{cite news|title='Save Miller Show' calls top 150,000|author=Deborah Hastings|agency=Associated Press|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19920804&id=B_xNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oIsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5122,643705&hl=en}}</ref> Despite Tribune Entertainment having promised Miller a nine-month commitment,<ref name=Phil/> the show was cancelled after seven months, with Tribune CEO saying the show wasn't making the ratings growth needed to continue.<ref>{{cite news|authorlink=Daniel Cerone|first=Daniel|last=Cerone|title=Tribune Cancels Nighttime Talk Show 'Dennis Miller'|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1992-07-18/business/fi-3649_1_dennis-miller|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1992-07-18|accessdate=2014-02-02}}</ref>
Arsenio Hall, still angered by "The Booking Wars," reacted to the news of Miller's cancellation by saying "He should be staying and punk-ass Leno should be going."<ref name=Harris/>
During the final week of Miller's show, taped after the cancellation press release, he announced a 1-900 phone number for fans to call and ask for the show to be continued. The number received around 150,000 calls and the charge for calling it made between $40-$50,000, which was donated to the Pediatric AIDS Foundation. Miller said he was touched by the outpouring and said he had only expected at most 20,000 calls.<ref name=Hastings/> Also during the final week, he took on a sharper edge that, to some reviewers, such as Phil Rosenthal, showed "just how much unfulfilled promise the show held for the same viewers who love NBC's ''Late Night With David Letterman'' or even [[Comedy Central]]'s cult favorite ''[[Night After Night with Allan Havey]]''." He jokingly looked into the camera and begged CBS Entertainment president Jeff Sagansky for a job; he had [[Julia Sweeney]] appear as her androgynous SNL character Pat and serenade him mimicking [[Bette Midler]]'s song for the retiring Johnny Carson. When a skit began to fail he moved the man with the cue-cards on camera.<ref name=Rosenthal/>
Miller also openly complained that getting guests had become increasingly difficult after Leno took over from Carson. He began openly accusing Leno's agent Helen Kushnick of unethical strong-arm booking tactics, which was a charge previously made by Arsenio Hall.<ref name=Abbott>{{cite news|title=Dennis Miller's Soft Side Starts To Compete With His Smugness|date=November 5, 1992|author=Jim Abbott|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-11-05/lifestyle/9211040378_1_dennis-miller-miller-called-miller-found|work=Orlando Sentinel}}</ref><ref name=Rosenthal/> Miller blasted Leno and Kushnick's press conference earlier that month that denied such tactics were being used.<ref name=Rosenthal/> After the cancellation Miller told an interviewer "I don't like Jay and ''The Tonight Show''. We just had problems, and I don't like the way they do business. ... There are ways to book shows and be tactful about it. Arsenio is very classy about it. The other show is not very tactful about it."<ref>{{cite news|title=Dennis Miller|work=Lodi News-Sentinel|date=September 4, 1992|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2245&dat=19920904&id=za8zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=njIHAAAAIBAJ&pg=5172,578334&hl=en}}</ref> Elsewhere Miller said that while he had only met Hall twice, "He's a legitimate human being who doesn't bullshit you." He called Hall classy and expressed interest at becoming better friends. In contrast, he said of Leno, "Jay and I were very good friends at one point. I don’t think I'd talk to him again, nor would he want to talk to me."<ref name=Hastings/>
Reviewers held that along with problems with booking guests, Miller had a tough time reconciling his caustic stand-up comedian stage presence that savaged his targets with that of interviewer where he cozied up to his subjects—though he was getting better near the end.<ref name=Rosenthal/>
On Miller's last show he, mimicking political party nomination races, said, "I release all my delegates to Arsenio and David Letterman." Miller then made an appearance on Hall's show.<ref name=Harris/>
There was speculation about what Miller might do after the cancellation, with The Associated Press reporting that all four network television stations had approached his business manager after the cancellation.<ref name=Hastings/> Miller went back to stand-up comedy, performing at colleges and preparing for an HBO special. He told a reporter, "Part of me would like to do another [talk show], but the other side says, 'Who needs the headaches?'". The competitive side of me wants to do another one, and I think something eventually will come up in TV."<ref name=Abbott/>
When Leno's ratings began to erode a few months into taking the ''Tonight Show'' from Carson, Miller told a reporter that he had always anticipated as much but now was not in a position to capitalize on it. He also expressed some anger at Tribune for pulling the plug by July rather than fulfilling its commitment to him which was at least until September (a promise they had repeated as late as May). He felt they had "a short fuse" and the company "wasn't a fan of me."<ref name=Abbott/><ref name=Rosenthal>{{cite news|title=Miller's Funky Charm Didn't Fly on Late Night|date=July 29, 1992|author=Phil Rosenthal|work=Orlando Sentinel|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-07-29/lifestyle/9207280770_1_dennis-miller-miller-show-tonight-show}}</ref> Elsewhere he said, "I think they flinched. If you're going to get in you got to get in and stay there for a while."<ref name=Hastings/>
Since Leno had taken over ''The Tonight Show'' the program had begun competing with Miller and Arsenio Hall for the same younger-skewing audiences and celebrity guests. The strong-arm booking practices of (Leno's longtime manager, producer, and close friend) Helen Kushnick for ''The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'' came to a head by September 15, 1992. Country artists [[Travis Tritt]] and [[Trisha Yearwood]], both clients of talent manager Ken Kragen, had been dropped and banned from ''The Tonight Show'' because Kragen had refused to cancel an already-booked appearance for Tritt with Hall when Kushnick called.<ref name=Tritt>{{cite news|title=Tonight' Gives Tritt the Boot|date=September 15, 1992|author=Daniel Cerone|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-09-15/entertainment/ca-742_1_travis-tritt|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> By September 28, 1992, NBC announced: "Effective immediately, Helen Kushnick will no longer be the executive producer [of ''The Tonight Show'']." Leno protested the move and expressed his continued support, but having been told by NBC that either she goes or both she and he go, did not make any ultimatums. ''Tonight Show'' insiders said Kushnick didn't let Leno get involved in production or booking and lied to him if he asked questions about it, and the two of them "have this sick, twisted, Hitchcock mother-son thing going."<ref>{{cite news|title=Goodbye Helen Kushnick|author=Lisa Schwarzbaum|date=October 2, 1992|work=Entertainment Weekly|url=http://ew.com/article/1992/10/02/goodbye-helen-kushnick/}}</ref>
Miller, despite having been proven correct about his claims about Kushnick and ''The Tonight Show'', expressed an air of resignation about the whole experience, telling a reporter in November 1992, "Everything that Arsenio and I were saying has been borne out to be true, but that's old news now."<ref name=Abbott/>
In 1993 when David Letterman left NBC for CBS, he was asked by [[Rolling Stone]] which comedian he thought might be able to take over the NBC slot. He thought that Dana Carvey might be good, but pointed to Miller for the time slot due to seeing him on ''The Dennis Miller Show'' before it was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news|title=Letterman to Ex-bosses: Hire Dennis Miller for Show|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=January 29, 1993|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1993-01-29/news/9301290574_1_dennis-miller-david-letterman-bosses}}</ref> (The network eventually chose [[Conan O'Brien]]).
In 1994 Leno fired Kushnick, for among other things planting a story in the New York Post in 1991 that claimed NBC wanted Carson to retire so they could hire Leno and attract a younger audience and then lying to Leno that it wasn't she. In 1995, after the Kushnick firing, Miller called Leno and they apologized to each other. Miller told a reporter, "I just got fed up in private and decided to call Jay earlier this week, because life is too short."<ref>{{cite news|title=With his feud with Jay Leno ended, Dennis Miller is a sort-of happy guy|publisher=Knight Ridder Tribune|date=May 12, 1995|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-16951198.html}}</ref> Having re-established their friendship, Miller appeared on ''The Tonight Show'' on May 10, 1995, and Leno appeared on HBO's ''Dennis Miller Live'' on May 12, 1995.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jay Leno Another Feud is put to Rest|date=May 6, 1995|work=Spartanburg Herald-Journal|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19950506&id=27YeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bM8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6047,890983&hl=en}}</ref> Miller would appear several times on Leno's show afterwards, even being one of the comedian stand-ins delivering [[Michael Jackson]] jokes when [[Jay Leno#Michael Jackson trial|Leno was under a court-ordered gag order]] during the 2005 [[trial of Michael Jackson]].<ref>{{cite news|title=For Jay Leno, Michael Jackson Gags Are in Order|author=Lisa de Moraes|date=March 12, 2005|work=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A28632-2005Mar11.html}}</ref>
===''Dennis Miller Live''=== Beginning in 1994, Miller hosted ''[[Dennis Miller Live]]'', a half-hour talk show on [[HBO]]. The show's theme song was the [[Tears for Fears]] hit "[[Everybody Wants to Rule the World]]", and included a snippet of the song "[[Civilized]]" by the [[Rollins Band]]. The show was taped at [[CBS Television City]] on the same stage where ''[[The Price Is Right]]'' is taped. It utilized a small set and sparse lighting, and there was no band. It comprised mainly Miller, speaking to the largely-unseen studio audience, on a darkened stage.
Miller hosted one guest per show, with whom he would discuss the topic of the day. Early on, guests were all interviewed live via satellite, but soon most appeared live in the studio. There was also a call-in segment. The number was originally given as 1-800-LACTOSE. Later, he referred to it only by its numeric equivalent (1-800-522-8673). Within the time available, Miller typically could accommodate only two or three calls. He gradually eliminated call-ins in the last few seasons of the show.
Miller and his writing staff won five [[Emmy Award]]s during the show's run, which aired 215 episodes over nine years. HBO cancelled the show in 2002.
===''Monday Night Football''=== With the increasing popularity of cable television and its multiple channel and programming options, [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' found itself competing for viewers.<ref name=SI/> One of its main competitors for its target young male demographic was professional wrestling. A further sense of urgency struck ABC when [[NBC]] announced that it would be working with [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]]'s [[Vince McMahon]] to usher in a competing football league in 2001—the [[XFL]] that would encourage rougher play and air during the offseason of the [[National Football League|NFL]].<ref name=SI/>
ABC went through a series of different announcer combinations in rapid succession, trying to establish a booth dynamic that would recapture the public's imagination. By the close of the 1999 season, they were looking to make the fourth change in as many years.<ref name=SI/> By the end of the 1999 NFL season, ''Monday Night Football'' had its ratings decline for the fifth season in a row. Dropping from an average of 17.8% of U.S. televisions in 1994 to 13.7% by 1999. In an effort to turn things around, ABC fired [[Boomer Esiason]] who had been on the show for two years. They also convinced [[Don Ohlmeyer]], who had produced the show in the 1970s, to come out of retirement and gave him the authority to pick his own announcers (he had also established NBC's successful [[Must See TV]] line-up before retiring).<ref name=SI/><ref name=Booth>{{cite news|date=June 23, 2000|title=Dennis Miller, Fouts to 'Monday Night Football' booth|agency=Associated Press|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/2000/06/23/pro_292640.shtml#.WNm7R2_ytpg}}</ref> ABC Sports-President Howard Katz told The Associated Press he felt "''Monday Night Football'' was not as special as it used to be, and that's why we've taken the dramatic steps we've taken. We wanted to remove some of the sameness. We wanted to reinvent a little bit."<ref name=Booth/> Elsewhere Katz said "It may not work. We may find out that this is a bad idea. But I love taking the risk."<ref name=SI/> Ohlmeyer set out to try and recapture the viewer excitement of the [[Howard Cosell]] and [[Don Meredith]] era.<ref name=Booth/><ref name=Edge>{{cite news|title=ABC Lives on Edge with Dennis Miller|date=June 23, 2000|author=Larry Stewart|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jun/23/sports/sp-44165}}</ref>
ABC told the AP that each open position had around twenty viable candidates vying for it, who auditioned by sitting with [[Al Michaels]] (whom ABC had retained) and 'calling' the previous season AFC playoff game [[Music City Miracle|between Tennessee and Buffalo]].<ref name=Booth/> Miller auditioned on June 12, 2000, sitting with Michaels in a Los Angeles studio to do such a mock broadcast.<ref name=SI/> Miller's NFL knowledge surprised those in attendance. He had grown up watching the 1970s championship Steelers and was an avid watcher of the NFL draft. He had even inquired about an announcing job with Fox after they had acquired rights to show [[Fox NFL|NFL games in 1994]].<ref name=SI/> Michaels later told an interviewer, "It was way beyond what we expected. I had no idea that he knew as much about football as he did. He made points that other analysts we brought in never made, and his points were more salient, more interesting, and better stated. He was giving his riff, analyzing the plays and providing the humor. Amazing would not be an overstatement. Then I thought, Maybe he's shooting his wad here, and that's all we're going to get. But he kept going. Hell, it was almost perfect. Don and I looked at each other and said, 'Wow. Where did this come from?'."<ref name=SI/>
ABC told Sports Illustrated about the three-month process Ohlmeyer went through, including going through hundreds of tapes, slimming down to 40 candidates, and conducting 20 auditions (which included Jimmy Johnson, Bill Parcells, Steve Young, and John Elway).<ref name=SI/> ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' noted that ESPN's [[Sterling Sharpe]] appeared to have been ABC's first choice but he had refused to return phone calls to ABC.<ref name=Edge/> Ohlmeyer had considered Miller early in the process, more as offering a rant segment within the broadcast, but he began to think of him in an expanded role.<ref name=SI/>
By late June 2000, it was announced that Miller had beaten out [[Rush Limbaugh]] and [[Tony Kornheiser]] (among others) for a job as [[color commentator]] on ABC's ''Monday Night Football''.<ref name=eonline>{{cite web |last=Armstrong |first=Mark |url=http://www.eonline.com/News/Items/0,1,6673,00.html |title=Dennis Miller Takes 'Monday Night' Pigskin|publisher=[[E!]]|date=June 22, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030221060805/http://www.eonline.com/News/Items/0,1,6673,00.html|archivedate=February 21, 2003}}</ref><ref name=Edge/> The L.A. Times called Miller's hiring "one of the boldest moves in sports television history," and noted that Miller, like Cosell, was "someone who is loved and hated," a person seen by some "as brilliant and witty; others see him as smug, pompous, and obnoxious."<ref name=Edge/> Show producer Ohlmeyer explained his thinking about hiring Miller: "Football is not played in [[St. Patrick's Cathedral (Manhattan)|St. Patrick's Cathedral]]. People watch football to have some fun. We want a telecast that's relevant, successful, and unpredictable. If it doesn't work out, no amount of buzz will save us."<ref name=Booth/> Miller praised the producer, saying "I admire Ohlmeyer's cojones. ... I think I'm a pretty quirky hire. I admire him for that."<ref name=SI/>
After the announcement, Miller appeared on the July 3, 2000, cover of ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' with the title "Can Dennis Miller Save 'Monday Night Football?'".<ref name=Shockwaves>{{cite news|title=Hiring of Dennis Miller Sends Shockwaves Through Industry|date=December 21, 2005|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2005/12/Issue-70/$MNF-On-ABC-1970-2005/Hiring-Of-Dennis-Miller-Sends-Shockwaves-Through-Industry.aspx|work=Street & Smith's Sports Business Daily}}</ref><ref name=SI>{{cite news|title='Live From New York, It's Monday Night!'|author=S.L. Price|url=https://www.si.com/vault/2000/07/03/283883/quotlive-from-new-york-its-monday-nightquot-abcs-surprise-hiring-of-dennis-miller-to-man-the-booth-with-al-michaels-and-dan-fouts-may-put-the-buzz-back-in-monday-night-football|date=July 3, 2000|work=Sports Illustrated}}</ref> Miller told reporters that he would not be trying to dominate the show. Both he and Ohlmeyer said his role would not be that of a comedian. Miller stated, "I'm going to try to stay in the background and ask questions a fan would ask. The rants are my HBO show and I won't try to recreate that. I'm going to try to integrate myself in a three-man scheme."<ref name=Booth/>
Miller and the new broadcasting team (hold-over Al Michaels on play-by-play, [[Dan Fouts]] as analyst, and [[Eric Dickerson]] with [[Melissa Stark]] reporting from the sidelines) began airing through the preseason, starting on July 31, 2000, in the preseason Hall of Fame Game between the [[New England Patriots]] and the [[San Francisco 49ers]].<ref name=Tulsa>{{cite news|title=Tulsa-bound comedian Dennis Miller riffs on SNL, MNF and the origin of spin|date=January 1, 2017|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/scene/tv/tulsa-bound-comedian-dennis-miller-riffs-on-snl-mnf-and/article_cdeb7b62-0ee9-5a78-ad71-6463eb913b6c.html|author=Jimmie Tramel|work=Tulsa World}}</ref> The show's official season opener was on September 4, 2000 with the [[Denver Broncos]] at the defending [[Super Bowl XXXIV|Super Bowl]] champion [[History of the St. Louis Rams|St. Louis Rams]].<ref name=Booth/> Miller's performance at the official opener was met with mixed reviews. AP and ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' held that Miller had improved from preseason, but ''[[The Washington Times]]'' said he "comes off as being a smug, smarmy, smirking sort," and ''[[The Toronto Star]]'' suggested, "Send Miller back to the Comedy Channel. ... This guy just isn't very good."<ref name=Shockwaves/>
Throughout Miller's Football coverage his commentary was sprinkled with esoteric references.<ref name=annotatedmiller>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/abcsports/mnf/s/annotatedmiller/archive.html |title=The Annotated Dennis Miller Archive |publisher=ESPN |date=2002-01-14 |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> A common Miller-ism was after a [[Hail Mary pass]] fell incomplete, he would say "Hail Mary is denied—[[separation of church and state]]." He also once referred to "[[The Greatest Show on Turf]]"—the [[St. Louis Rams]] receiving corps—as the "Murderer's Row of Haste." Online options arose to offer definitions to references made by Miller on ''Monday Night Football'': a website called "Dennis Miller Demystified", [[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'s "Annotated Dennis Miller", and the ''Shadowpack'' (a "content aggregator, formatter, and e-commerce app"<ref>{{cite news|title=Shadowpack|date=August 1, 2000,|publisher=PCMag.Com|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,24609,00.asp}}</ref>) giving real-time explanations on [[personal digital assistant]]. Miller announced he was flattered by such attention.<ref name=Veale>{{cite news|work=New York Times|title=Word for Word/Dennis Miller Decoded; Veni, Vidi, Vici, Babe: Football for Eggheads|author=Scott Veale|date=December 10, 2000|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/10/weekinreview/word-for-word-dennis-miller-decoded-veni-vidi-vici-babe-football-for-eggheads.html}}</ref>
As his first season progressed Miller's critics held that "he sounds scripted."<ref name=Shockwaves/> The show's ratings continued to decline; in 2001 the show had 16.8 million viewers, down from 18.5 million the year before and below the 19.4 million of pre-Miller 1999.<ref name=LS>{{cite news|title='Monday Night Football' Hauls in Madden|date=March 1, 2002|author=Larry Stewart|work=Los Angeles Times|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/mar/01/news/mn-30459}}</ref> As the ratings did not improve, writers from ''[[Newsweek]]'' and ''[[USA Today]]'' began openly calling for Miller to be let go.<ref name=Shockwaves/> Despite the questionable ratings, Miller and Fouts signed a contract for a third year.<ref name=TAE/>
Despite having hired Miller and Fouts for another year, ABC began negotiations with veteran football commentator [[John Madden]]. Madden had worked at Fox Sports for eight years since the network had won the contract for the NFC Conference games away from CBS in 1998. Since getting the NFL contract, Fox had lost $4.4 billion (losing $387 million due to the contract in 2001 alone), and was looking to cut programming costs.<ref name=Isidore>{{cite news|author=Chris Isidore|date=February 28, 2002|title=Madden leaves Fox for ABC|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/02/28/companies/fox_madden/}}</ref> Madden's contract for the next year would cost Fox $8 million, so when ABC was approaching Madden, Fox agreed to let him out of his remaining year on their contract.<ref name=Isidore/> Despite having been hired for another year, Miller and Fouts were replaced by Madden, who was signed on February 28, 2002 for $5 million a year for four years.<ref name=Shockwaves/><ref name=LS/> (Fouts remained with ABC, being moved to cover college football; Miller and Eric Dickerson were let go.)<ref name=Isidore/>
Miller later reflected, "The football thing was fun for me. I was in the middle of a maelstrom and I just decided not to pay attention to it because, for me, getting hired was a freakish act of nature. I had never gone to a football game. ... I remember the day I heard that John Madden had quit Fox (and) I remember calling Dan Fouts that afternoon and saying, 'Get ready, babe, we’re getting whacked.'... I don't have any hard feelings."<ref name=Shockwaves/> Elsewhere he said, "As soon as Madden left Fox, I pretty much knew I was going to be whacked. Here was Madden, the [[Pliny the Elder]] of football announcers. And they were going to stay with the kid? I was having fun. I had alienated half the community, and probably half of them liked me. Which is pretty much my batting average. I began to see maybe a decade ago that my career was never going to be in complete approval. I wasn't endearing."<ref name=Joke/> When asked about "the Dennis Miller experiment," Madden told ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' that he thought people tuned into ''Monday Night'' to view the game and not entertainment; "If I go to watch a comedian, I don't expect a football game to break out."<ref>{{cite news|work=Sports Illustrated|date=July 29, 2002|page=37|url=https://www.si.com/vault/issue/703748/39/2|title=Monday Evening Quarterback|author=Michael Silver}}</ref> Al Michaels, while overjoyed to work with Madden, praised Miller, saying, "what he tried to do was the hardest thing ever attempted in broadcasting. No other non-football person or someone of that ilk could have pulled it off as well as he did."<ref name=LS/>
In 2010, [[TV Guide Network]] listed Miller's stint at No. 12 on their list of ''25 Biggest TV Blunders'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20100302tvguide01|title=Breaking News – TV Guide Network's "25 Biggest TV Blunders" Special Delivers 3.3 Million Viewers|date=2010-03-02|publisher=thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=2010-03-10}}</ref> while Awful Announcing put him at No. 1 in their list of the ''Top 10 Sports Media Busts''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2012-articles/top-10-sports-media-busts.html|title=Top 10 Sports Media Busts|work=Awful Announcing|first=Ryan|last=Yoder|date=January 25, 2012|accessdate = 2015-12-27}}</ref>
===CNBC show=== {{Infobox television|show_name=Dennis Miller|image=|caption=Dennis Miller on his self-titled CNBC show|runtime=60 minutes|creator=| starring= Dennis Miller|opentheme=|endtheme=|country=USA|network=[[CNBC]]|first_aired=January 26, 2004|last_aired=May 13, 2005|num_episodes=220|italic_title=no}} E! News later reported that [[MSNBC]] had considered Miller for a 2002 prime-time talk show, but instead went with [[Phil Donahue]].<ref name=Byrne/>
By 2003, Miller began providing regular commentary for the [[Fox News]] show ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]''. [[E! News]] reported that he was a serious candidate to provide commentary on the show, but the deal didn't go through for unknown reasons.<ref name=Byrne>{{cite news|work=E! News|title= Dennis Miller Does CNBC|author=Bridget Byrne|date=October 31, 2003|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/46179/dennis-miller-does-cnbc}}</ref>
CNBC had seen a slide in its ratings since [[Brian Williams]] was moved to NBC to replace retiring [[Tom Brokaw]] in its ''[[NBC Nightly News]]''.<ref name=Byrne/> The network hadn't had a well-known personality in its prime-time lineup since the departure of [[Geraldo Rivera]] for Fox News in 2001.<ref name=BD/> The nighttime audience for CNBC was smaller than its cable competitors, causing the network to look for a new direction.<ref name=BD>{{cite news|title=CNBC Gives Dennis Miller a Daily Show|date=October 31, 2003|work=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/31/business/cnbc-gives-dennis-miller-a-daily-show.html}}</ref> While it had been showing mostly business-oriented talk shows, such as ''[[Kudlow & Cramer]]'' and ''Capital Report'',<ref name=BD/> NBC Entertainment president [[Jeff Zucker]] approached Miller with an offer to do a prime-time political show weeknights in CNBC's 9 p.m. ([[Eastern Time Zone|ET]]) slot, which placed him against Fox's Bill O'Reilly.<ref name=Byrne/><ref name=Joke>{{cite news|work=New York Times|title=The Joke Is on Liberals, Says Dennis Miller, Host of His Own Show Again|author=Bernard Weinraub|date=January 15, 2004|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/15/arts/the-joke-is-on-liberals-says-dennis-miller-host-of-his-own-show-again.html}}</ref>
Miller accepted the offer and the show, produced by NBC Studios,<ref name=BD/> began on January 26, 2004 called, simply, ''Dennis Miller''.<ref name=Joke/> CNBC announced that they were "comfortable with an unabashed Bush fan in the middle of its prime-time schedule in an election year."<ref name=BCM/> Their president [[Pamela Thomas-Graham]] said, "When we hired Dennis, we knew exactly what his political beliefs were and his viewers will hear them. The reason we hired him is we think he's witty, smart and interesting. He's part of a lineup. He's not the only person in the lineup." She contrasted his political leanings to that of John McEnroe's, whose own talk show followed Miller's in the lineup.<ref name=BCM/> The group [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting]] objected that one of the show's producers was Mike Murphy, who was an adviser to Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, and charged that CNBC was setting up a conflict of interest.<ref name=BCM/>
Miller promised to serve as "'an [[ombudsman]]' who will tell it like it is and become 'incensed' on the viewer's behalf".<ref name=Bernhard/> Miller said he wanted to change his approach from previous talk-show work, striving for seriousness and substance by researching issues, to avoid becoming an "irony-lalapalooza like it's been in the past. ...I don't want to become some ageing hipster who pisses on everything."<ref name=NMax/> Stylistically Miller was seen as "attempting to be serious, angry, and funny all at the same time," and the show was compared to that of [[Bill Maher]].<ref name=Bernhard/> When asked if he had the credentials to do a quasi-news show, Miller stressed he was an entertainer. "I don't have credibility, I'm a comedian. I'm not [[Ed Murrow]] up on the roof in a London Fog reporting on the Blitz."<ref name=BCM/>
In the beginning of the series, Miller had a chimpanzee on the show named Ellie, who was declared a "consultant."<ref name=Bernhard>{{cite news|work=LA Weekly|title=Miller's Crossing|author=Brendan Bernhard|date=March 4, 2004|url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/millers-crossing-2137853}}</ref> This was a nod to the early days of the ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'' show and their mascot [[J. Fred Muggs]].<ref name=NMax>{{cite news|title=Dennis Miller: Why I 'Ascended' to the Right|date=February 4, 2004|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Pre-2008/Dennis-MillerWhyAscended-/2004/02/04/id/679020/|work=Newsmax|author=James Hirsen}}</ref> After a few appearances Ellie was replaced by a smaller, friendlier chimp named Mo.<ref name=Bernhard/> Reviewers theorized Ellie was let go "perhaps because she pressed the [[Howard Dean]] [[Howard Dean#Iowa Caucus setback and the .22Dean Scream.22 media gaffe|'scream']] button on Miller's desk one too many times."<ref name=Bernhard/> Mo was noted for swinging across the studio on a rope, doing somersaults on the sofa while giving the appearance of reading ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', and for nuzzling Miller while he gave his monologue.<ref name=Bernhard/> Miller appeared to enjoy Mo's presence and his personality.<ref name=Bernhard/>
The hour-long show contained a daily news segment called "The Daily [[Rorschach inkblot test|Rorschach]]", which were wordy riffs on the news events, reminiscent of his role on SNL's ''Weekend Update'' and his HBO show.<ref name=Bernhard/> Reviewers felt Miller's riffs would benefit from a live audience for him to feed off of, and the show incorporated a "nightclub-style audience of 100 or so" beginning on March 9, 2004.<ref name=Bernhard/> A sign giving out the toll-free telephone number to order tickets was held up by Mo.<ref name=Bernhard/>
For the first half of the show Miller interviewed someone held to be able to explain a particular current issue in the news. ''L.A. Weekly'' remarked, "Miller may be up front about his own political affiliation, even to the point of shilling for the Republicans, but despite his increasingly aggressive America-first humor, he is unusually evenhanded in his selection of guests."<ref name=Bernhard/> Miller had laid out his vision for such interviews before the show began airing, telling The Associated Press, "I don't want it to be a screaming shriekfest. I want it to be a pretty reasoned discourse. I don't care what [[Gary Coleman]] thinks about Afghanistan, which to me was the flaw of '[[Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher|Politically Correct]]' towards the end."<ref name=BCM/>
For its second half, the show also featured a panel discussion dubbed "The Varsity", which offered a wide variety of political viewpoints on current topics. Frequent "Varsity" panelists included [[Ed Schultz]], [[Gloria Allred]], [[Willie Lewis Brown, Jr.|Willie Brown]], [[David Horowitz (conservative writer)|David Horowitz]], [[Mickey Kaus]], [[Steve Katz (politician)|Steven Katz]], [[Lawrence O'Donnell]], [[Phil Hendrie]], and [[Harry Shearer]]. In these segments, Miller acted "less like a host than a fellow conversationalist, and seems as happy to listen as to interrupt. But he does get in a few wisecracks."<ref name=Bernhard/> Miller was praised by ''[[LA Weekly]]'' for approaching the panel in a "relatively relaxed and straightforward attitude." Despite having "worked briefly as a commentator for ''Hannity and Colmes'' on Fox, he's far from being a [[Rupert Murdoch|Murdochian]] attack dog, and he often sits there and sucks it up while people tell him just how awful the administration of his beloved commander-in-chief really is. ... Miller, it turns out, is considerably more interested in 'diversity' than some of his liberal counterparts."<ref name=Bernhard/>
Fellow SNL alum [[Tim Meadows]] and ''[[Last Comic Standing]]'''s [[Ant (comedian)|Ant]] portrayed humorous field correspondents which served as a break between the political humor.<ref name=Carl/>
The show was openly pro-President George W. Bush and it debuted at the same time that [[John Kerry]] had become the Democratic front-runner. The inability to find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, a budget that was seen as out of control, and a resentment over the President's tough-talking cowboy image had all caused a major decline in President Bush's approval numbers.<ref name=Bernhard/> While Miller's rating started out well with his first episode interviewing his friend Schwarzenegger (''The New York Times'' put the figure at 746,000 people, which was a big number in the eyes of CNBC), by March 2004 his numbers had slipped to 300,000.<ref name=Bernhard/> This was contrasted by ''[[The Daily Show]]'' with [[Jon Stewart]], which attracted 1.9 million viewers, and which aired at the later time slot of 11 pm.<ref name=Bernhard/>
By April 2005, Miller's viewership had declined to 107,000 (a 59% drop from the year before).<ref name=CNNM>{{cite news|title=CNBC cancels 'Dennis Miller'|date=May 12, 2005|work=CNN Money|url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/12/news/newsmakers/cnbc_miller/}}</ref> CNBC canceled the show in May 2005 as part of the network's move to refocus on financial news (airings of ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' and shows hosted by John McEnroe and [[Tina Brown]] were also cancelled).<ref name=CNNM/> Miller's show was replaced with a second airing of ''[[Mad Money with Jim Cramer]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dennis Miller & Me|author=Asra Nomani|date=May 31, 2005|work=the American Prospect}}</ref><ref name=CNNM/>
===Guest appearances and commercials=== Miller has appeared as a guest or guest star on various shows, including ''[[Boston Public]]'', ''[[The Daily Show]]'', ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]'', ''[[NewsRadio]]'', ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'', ''[[Norm Macdonald|The Norm Show]]'', ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'', ''[[SportsCenter]]'', "[[Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives]]", and late-night talk shows ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]'', and ''[[WWE Raw]]''.<ref>{{IMDb name|0588222}}</ref>
Miller hosted the [[MTV Video Music Awards]] in 1995 and 1996. He was also the host of HBO's 1996 series of election specials, ''Not Necessarily the Election''.
In 2003, he made a guest appearance on the [[Adult Swim]] show ''[[Space Ghost Coast to Coast]]''.
He has appeared in various television commercials, serving as a spokesman for [[M&M's]] candies, 10-10-220 long distance service, and the Internet service provider [[NetZero]]. About these activities he has remarked: "Everybody has to [[sell out]] at some point to make a living. I'm a family man. I sold out to make an M&M commercial. They offer incredible amounts of money, and I say, ‘What can I do to sell one more piece of candy for you? Do you want me to hug the M&M?’"<ref>{{cite web|work=[[USA Today]]|url=http://159.54.226.237/97_issues/970720/970720talk_dennis_miller.html|title=Straight Talk. The cranky comedian "rants" for a living. But don't try it at home, he says.|first=Jeffrey|last=Zaslow|issue=July 18–20, 1997|date=July 18, 1997}}</ref> Miller also did a short [[Business-to-business|B2B]] commercial for Blockbuster/IBM partnership company, New Leaf Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://retailgeek.com/retail/future-of-retail-as-seen-in-1992|title=Future of Retail (as seen in 1992)|publisher=retailgeek.com|accessdate=21 September 2014}}</ref> On February 27, 2012, Miller guest starred on ''[[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|Hawaii 5-0]]'' in the episode "Lekio," alongside guest star [[James Caan]].
===Return to Fox News Channel=== On September 21, 2006, Miller returned to [[Fox News| Fox News Channel]] with a two-and-a-half-minute commentary on [[illegal immigration]] during his "Real Free Speech" segment on ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]''.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,215178,00.html | publisher=Fox News Channel | title=Funnyman Dennis Miller Returns to FNC! | date=September 22, 2006}}</ref> He appeared on 13 of the 17 aired episodes of the comedy show ''[[The 1/2 Hour News Hour]]''. He had a weekly segment called "Miller Time" on ''[[The O'Reilly Factor]]'', and has also appeared on ''[[Red Eye w/ Greg Gutfeld]]'' under the pseudonym "Mansquito," a name Miller has pledged to use on future appearances on the network.
===Game shows=== Miller co-hosted the game show ''[[Grand Slam (US TV series)|Grand Slam]]'', which aired on [[Game Show Network|GSN]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/CA6449122.html |title=GSN Taps Dennis Miller To Host Grand Slam – 6/5/2007 12:56:00 am – Broadcasting & Cable |publisher=Broadcastingcable.com |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref>
For one month, Miller hosted ''[[Amne$ia]]'' for [[NBC]]. The show was a replacement program commissioned during the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike]] and was canceled once the strike was resolved and scripted programming returned to the network.
===''Sports Unfiltered'' on Versus=== In November 2007, [[NBCSN|Versus]] tapped Miller to host ''Sports Unfiltered'', a weekly one-hour sports talk show.<ref>{{cite web|author=rickchand |url=http://deadspin.com/355359/whither-sports-unfiltered-with-dennis-miller |title=Whither Sports Unfiltered With Dennis Miller? |publisher=Deadspin.com |date=2008-02-12 |accessdate=2011-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/dennis-miller-sports-41845/|title=Dennis Miller's Back in the Game with Sports Unfiltered|work=TV Guide|first=Kelly|last=McGettigan|date=November 6, 2007|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> It was canceled after eight episodes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cantstopthebleeding.com/he-even-makes-sports-boring-dennis-miller-cancelled-again|title=He Even Makes Sports Boring: Dennis Miller Cancelled Again|first=Ben|last=Schwartz|date=February 14, 2008|accessdate=December 12, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.episodate.com/tv-show/sports-unfiltered-with-dennis-miller|title=Sports Unfiltered with Dennis Miller|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref>
==Radio career==
===''The Dennis Miller Show''=== In January 2007, Miller signed a deal with [[Westwood One (1976–2011)|Westwood One]] (later acquired by Dial Global, which rebranded itself as [[Westwood One (current)|Westwood One]]) to launch ''[[The Dennis Miller Show (radio)|The Dennis Miller Show]]'', a weekday three-hour [[talk radio]] program.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSWEN204120070112 |title=Dennis Miller starting radio show on Westwood One |agency=Reuters |date= January 10, 2007|accessdate=2011-05-29}}</ref> The program debuted on March 26, 2007, and ran through February 27, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://affiliates.westwoodone.com/features/dennis-miller-show.asp |title=The Dennis Miller Show |publisher=Affiliates.westwoodone.com |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> The show's website<ref>{{cite web|first=Payam|last=Zarrabizadeh |url=http://www.dennismillerradio.com/ |title=The Official Home of Dennis Miller on the Web |publisher=Dennismillerradio.com |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> provided a live stream of the broadcast. The site also made archives of all shows available in MP3 format. The live feed was free, but a subscription to the Dennis Miller Zone (DMZ) was required in order to access archived broadcasts. The show aired on 250+ stations, many of which (especially in the major markets at the time of the show's launch) were owned by [[Salem Communications]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/archives/ic/2007/3/20/121544.shtml?s=ic |title=Dennis Miller Readies to Host Radio Show |publisher=Newsmax.com |date=2007-03-20 |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> airing on tape delay on some of those stations between 6–9 pm ET and 9 pm-12 am ET. Salem stations also aired a "best of" Miller show on Saturdays. His on-air sidekick "Salman" ([[David S. Weiss]]) also wrote for ''Dennis Miller Live''. His producer Christian Bladt previously appeared on-camera as dozens of different characters during the "Daily Rorschach" segment on his CNBC television show.
Miller's program included serious discussions about American culture, current events, politics, and their place in the global context.
